instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message:
This is my first post so go easy.
My guy that does these repairs fucked off to another company for more money so I'm trying to teach myself the ropes.

I have a MBP early 2015 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. Came in with water damage but working apart from a few keys.

No obvious signs on the board so just swapped the faulty keyboard. After fitting the board back to check if the new keyboard is okay, I get no fan spin or anything.

Ive checked a few rails with my limited knowledge and get the following

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>   5v
​<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>  0v
​<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>  0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  3.3v

Not sure if I've missed a rail to check but the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> @ 12.57v when it should be 8.6v doesn't look good. And the DCIN @ 16.6v is a bit low.

Any ideas?

Sorry for the noob first post if its missing obvious stuff.

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message: Inspect the board for corrosion first. Common area for these is around the SPI ROM and clock chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message:
its my first reply to anyone here 

as you told only few keys were not working 
means motherboard was fine booting up , only the keyboard was faulty 

if yes 

i feel there could be 2 reasons of motherboard going BAD ! 

check for water sign all over the board , check if any rasistance have turned black also 

another common mistake my enginner also do while replacing the hardware ,  they miss handle the board , the delicate compoments gets broken 

MAINLY those which have glass apperance , they mosly transfer voltages as per motherboard stage , even if they have a little crack they are not working properly ( such as <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> - there might me 6-7 on this board ) 

sorry soo many typing errors !!

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message:
Thank you for the advice. 

There shouldn't be any physical damage to the board while its out the laptop because it's just placed at the back of the bench out the way, and I did it myself.
I'll recheck for any corrosion tomorrow, then maybe give it an acid brush and a rinse with Iso around the areas you mentioned Duke.

I suspect the fact the board was moved has caused whatever little damage or corrosion existed to show its face.

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message:
No Title

Okay, so I looked around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> SPI and couldn't see anything obvious signs of corrosion ( see pic ) 

So I acid brushed the area and then brushed and bathed the whole board in Iso, then gave it a blast with the air line and heated. 

Plugged it back in and got <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and the S0 states, checked the CPU and it was pretty warm but still no fans. So connected up a screen and it fired up.

The fan doesn't come on when the DC is plugged in, or when the machine is first turned on like others, but it does spin up once it gets warm so I'm assuming this is normal for this board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message: Thank you for the advice Duke

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message: Fan does not spin up until warm on these newer models. So I guess we can call this one fixed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]MacBook Pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-08 No fan spin - Green/Orange light present
threads.message:
Hi
When you say "heated" what do you mean? Did you heat the whole board or just that area? How did you heat? Did you reflow? Thanks in advance as I having the same problem with the same board.
